Apollo 11 Moon LOnDing


"That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind"

The Domain


On the 20th July 1969 Neil Armstrong became the first person to step foot on the moon, marking a historic moment for the whole of humanity, and realising one of the most era-defining feats of the 20th century.

Alongside Edwin “Buzz” Aldrin and Michael Collins, Armstrong reached the moon as part of the Apollo 11 Project, launched by President Kennedy in 1961, with the explicit aim of landing a man on the moon and returning him back to earth before the close of the decade.

However, the Apollo 11 project was not simply about space exploration, scientific innovation, and the widening of humanity’s horizons. At the time, the United States was in fierce competition with its Cold War adversary, the Soviet Union – a rivalry now referred to as the Space Race. The Space Race was not just a matter of technological superiority; it represented a battle between two ideologies, two ways of being, and two ways of ruling. The USA’s triumph in the Space Race was therefore hugely symbolic.

Nevertheless, despite bountiful documentary evidence, there are many who did – and still do – cast doubt upon the veracity of the Apollo 11 moon landing, viewing it as a large-scale, national-level conspiracy aimed at duping the world into believing in the might and power of the United States.

Moon LOnDing is a Linked Open Data project which seeks to explore the organisation and representation of knowledge connected to the Apollo 11 moon landing, focusing on three core narratives:

  • The historic and era-defining nature of the achievement, as evidenced in many references to the moon landing in popular culture throughout the decades
  • The political background which was the backdrop and impetus of the moon landing, namely the Cold War and the Space Race
  • The perduring doubts which surround the moon landing, manifest in the proliferation of conspiracy theories, despite physical evidence to the contrary

Objects


Ten objects relating to the Apollo 11 moon landing have been carefully selected to represent and interlink each of the aforementioned narrative threads (impact on popular culture, political background, doubts and conspiracies).

Knowledge Organisation


Conceptual Map


The first step in the process of organising knowledge related to the Apollo 11 moon landing was to create a conceptual map in order to visualise our items. We placed the main concept of our domain, the Apollo 11 moon landing itself, at the centre of our diagram, with our objects surrounding it.

We connected each item from our collection to the Apollo 11 moon landing and to an array of metadata which corresponded to the most important people, places, things, and dates connected to that specific object.




ER Model


We then converted our conceptual map into an entity-relationship model by abstracting from particulars to more platonic, universal concepts.

For example: the authors/creators of our items were converted into the generic class ‘person’; the specific dates of creation of our items were converted into the generic class ‘date’; the museums and cultural centres that house our items were converted into the generic class ‘institution’; our items themselves were converted into generic classes, such as ‘book’, ‘physical artefact’, ‘recording’, etc.




Metadata Scouting


In order to progress our organisation of knowledge related to the Apollo 11 moon landing, we identified the metadata standards employed by the provider institution of each of our objects.

In some cases we were not able to directly access or retrieve the metadata standards, such as in the cases of the National Air and Space Museum and Worldcat.

After contacting the National Air and Space Museum, we discovered that it uses a software system called ‘The Museum System’ for cataloguing its physical artefacts. Unfortunately, we were unable to access this software. As a substitute, we identified CIDOC-CRM as an appropriate metadata standard for the museal context.

In the case of Worldcat, since the metadata standards used by this provider were unclear, we decided to use Marc21, which supplements the MODS standard used by other bibliographic items in our collection.

The metadata standards that we chose to align are therefore:

  1. Dublin Core: composed of fifteen main elements for describing resources, we employed this standard as a reference for all the others, due to its generality
  2. MMD XML schema: an XML based document format to represent music metadata, easy to read, powerful and extensible
  3. DACS (Description Archives: A Content Standard): an output-neutral set of rules for describing archives, personal papers, and manuscript collections, which can be applied to all material types
  4. EAD (Encoded Archival Description): an XML standard used for encoding archival finding aids, which mixes the archival workflow with the need for electronic document processing
  5. Marc21: a carrier for bibliographic information about printed and manuscript textual materials, computer files, maps, music, continuing resources, visual materials, and mixed materials
  6. MODS: schema for a bibliographic element set that may be used for a variety of purposes, and particularly for library applications
  7. CIDOC-CRM (CIDOC Conceptual Reference Model): an extensible ontology to create a reference model, employed by museums and other cultural institutions to describe their collections
  8. Schema.org: launched by Yahoo, Bing and Google, an initiative which strives to provide its users with a framework via which to use structured data mark-up for web pages
  9. LCDRG (Lifecycle Data Requirements Guide): outlines the metadata standards used by the NARA (National Archives and Records Administration) for the permanent description of archival materials

Item Type of item Provider Metadata standard
Special Message to Congress on Urgent National Needs Audio recording John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum LCDRG (Lifecycle Data Requirements Guide)

Metadata Alignment


After having identified, chosen, and analysed the metadata standards for our objects, we carried out a process of metadata alignment. To do this, we categorised the informal, natural language predicates from our conceptual map and ER model into: who, what, where, and when. We then identified the most appropriate label for each of these predicates from the aforementioned metadata standards.


  • Who

  • Where

  • When

  • What

Theoretical Model


With all the information acquired in the previous steps, we were able to analyse the Apollo 11 moon landing and the items in our collection from a different perspective. Most pertinently, we were now able to see the connections and relationships among the various entities of our maps.

Hence we were able to develop further our ER model, in natural language, adding several more links related to the people, places, dates and subjects of the Apollo 11 moon landing. Our primary objective in this step was twofold: firstly, to enhance the relationships between our objects and, secondly, to enhance our representation of the three narrative threads we had previously outlined as the focus of our knowledge organisation process (namely, impact on popular culture, political background, doubts and conspiracies).

New relationships and interlinkages included:

  • Expanding our description of the people involved with the items chosen, through the inclusion of dates of birth, names, and roles
  • Making explicit the relationships among the people involved in the Apollo 11 mission
  • Adding major temporal and spatial notions, mostly connected with the main event of the Apollo 11 moon landing, such as the launch and landing dates
  • Enhancing our representation of the ‘2001: A Space Odyssey’ book by including the fact that it is based on a work that had two expressions: the book version, as already included, but also a film version, the screenplay of which was written by Stanley Kubrick, who also contributed to the writing of the book version
  • Including the link between Arthur C. Clarke, author of the ‘2001: A Space Odyssey’ book, and the ‘First on the Moon’ book, for which Clarke wrote the epilogue
  • Adding new concepts that allowed us to highlight the three narrative threads which were the focus of our knowledge organisation. For example: adding ‘the Space Race’ and ‘the Soviet Union’, and linking these to the ‘Special Message to Congress’, enabled us to emphasise the political background of the Apollo 11 moon landing. Additionally, adding ‘conspiracy theories’, and linking this to the ‘We Never Went to the Moon’ book and the ‘2001: A Space Odyssey’ book enabled us to stress the doubts which surrounded the moon landing (in particular, it allowed us to interlink Stanley Kubrick, contributor to the latter book, to the dissemination of conspiracy theories)

Knowledge Representation


Data Description


Using our conceptual model we extrapolated a series of RDF triples about each object. Each row of the following tables represents a statement about each item, whilst the columns represent the subject, predicate, and object of each statement.

These tables can be downloaded as CSV files via the following links: "First on the Moon" || Spacesuit || "We Never Went to the Moon" || Memorandum || "Man on the Moon" || Message to Congress || Image || Medal || "Waterloo" || "2001: A Space Odyssey"

  • Image

  • Medal

  • "Waterloo"

  • "2001: A Space Odyssey"

Special Message to Congress on Urgent National Needs


A speech given by President Kennedy on the 25th May 1961, declaring his intention to put a man on the moon and to bring him back to earth by the end of the decade. It is held by the John F. Kennedy Library.

Waterloo


An episode from the 7th season of the TV show “Mad Men”, a series set in the 1960s. In this episode, we see not only the characters watch the moon landing on TV but we also witness the multifarious, and often discordant, opinions surrounding the event. The episode is referenced from its IMBD record.

Medal, Commemorative, Apollo 11


A medal created by Constantino Affer in honour of the moon landing, depicting Neil Armstrong as he takes his first steps on the moon. The medal is made from bronze using a high-relief technique. It is stored at the Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Centre, Virginia, a subsidiary of the National Air and Space Museum, whose main site is in Washington D.C.

First on the Moon


A book detailing the Apollo 11 project generally, as well as the moon landing and return to earth, published in 1970. Written by the crew who took part in the mission: Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin, and Michael Collins. The book is referenced from its Library of Congress record.

Apollo 11 Launch Images Burgess: NASM-9A13960


One image from a collection of digitized images taken by Tim Burgess during a preflight press conference on 5th July 1969 at the NASA Manned Spacecraft Centre in Houston, Texas. The image depicts the crew of Apollo 11: Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin, and Michael Collins. The images are held by the National Air and Space Museum, Washington D.C.

2001: A Space Odyssey


A science fiction novel written by Arthur C. Clarke and published in 1968. It depicts landing on the moon prior to it happening, offering a glimpse of contemporary imagination in this respect. The novel was written concurrently with Stanley Kubrick’s film version, of the same name. The book is referenced from its Library of Congress record.

Pressure Suit, A7-L, Armstrong, Apollo 11, Flown


The spacesuit worn by Neil Armstrong during the Apollo 11 mission, commissioned by NASA and made out of white beta cloth. It is held by the National Air and Space Museum, Washington D.C.

We Never Went to the Moon


A book propounding that the moon landing was a hoax, published in 1976. The book was written by Bill Kaysing, who worked at the Rocketdyne Propulsion Field Laboratory during the period in which the engine and components for the Apollo 11 project were planned. The book is referenced from its WorldCat record.

Man on the Moon


A song written and performed by the band R.E.M., released as the second single from their 1992 album “Automatic for the People”. The song reached number 30 on the US Billboard Hot 100 and number 18 in the UK Singles Chart. The song is referenced from its MusicBrainz record.

Memorandum to President Nixon


A speech written by speechwriter, William Saffire, for President Nixon. It contains the text of a speech that was prepared for the President in the case that the Apollo 11 crew were unable to return to earth following the moon landing, representing the danger of the mission they were undertaking. The document is held by the National Archives Catalogue of the United States.
